Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2015 06:35PM dawny wrote: Garlikbread, a short rundown on my history. Diagnosed May 2011, stage IV, large lump in breast, spot in lung, and lymph nodes in neck and chest. I was ER/PR- HER2+. I had Abraxane and Herceptin that took me to NED. Then a new lump in same breast and lymph nodes in chest again. I had Kadcycla on a clinical trial, had progression in lump, came off the trial. I decided to have a single mx, and radiation to the chest wall. Pathology from mx showed receptor change to triple neg. I wrongly assumed that if I was going on a HER2 clinical trial, that receptors had been checked. I was very peeved that I had gone through six months of Kadcycla hell, without a chance of it possibly helping at all. The good news now is that I am now NED again, for almost two years. I decided against reconstruction, as I didn't want the possibility of further complications either. I can't understand how your onc can say no to receptors changing. How can that be known without testing? I hope you get some clarity, has surgery been scheduled for you? x

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 03:35AM dawny wrote: Hi all, we are having a boiling hot day here in m  little part of the world (Geelong, Australia) it is 36 degrees celsius, (I think that is about 102?) So my husband has taken my children to a pool to swim, whilst I pack to accompany my 11 yr old son to school camp tomorrow.  It is at a place called Sovereign Hill in Ballarat, which is an old goldmining town.  You can still pan for gold there, go for tours in the mines,etc.  It is setup the way it was back in the 1850's, the teachers in the classrooms will have canes, although the kids have been told they definitely won't be hit with them!!.  So I have to wear a huge hoop dress, no make up, no watch, no mobile phone (Yikes)  One of the notes that came home from school said that all mothers must wear their hair in plaits or a bun, he he he, my hair is just a bit of fuzzy fluff on top of my head, with next to nothing on the sides!  I hope I don't get the cane! Hope you all have a good day Dawn

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2012 03:59AM dawny wrote: Hi Marsha I think a lot of anti-depressants vary slightly, depending on what you require.  I am on Zoloft, and I take 1 Ativan at night to help me sleep.  I feel so much better since I have been on this regime.  Before, I was bursting into tears every second minute!  I am not normally one to take medication if I can help it, but I figure it's bleeping cancer, I will take whatever will make my life as normal as I can, and without sleep, or being so anxious that you can't think straight doesn't do you or your family and friends, and favours.  Good luck Dawn

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2014 08:32PM dawny wrote: Hi Almasi, I was diagnosed at stage IV, with similar nodes to your mother, large breast lump, nodes in neck, centre of chest and underarm, but I also had a teeny weeny spot on my lung. ER/PR neg and HER2 Positive.  I had a lumpectomy, Abraxane and Herceptin which got me to NED ( no evidence of disease) it came back in the same breast and chest node, so I had a single mastectomy and radiation to the centre of the chest.  I am now NED again. After the mastectomy, pathology showed it had morphed to triple negative. I was diagnosed nearly 3 1/2 years ago, only on Herceptin now, sticking with that in case it morphs back to HER2 positive  😀  I hope this gives you some encouragement, I am doing really well, hopefully your mother will also.  Xxx

Posts.Title: EAD - Liz everyminute Mominator

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2016 09:06AM dawny wrote: Hi Kim, I was diagnosed stage IV from diagnoses over five years ago. I was er/pr neg and HER2 +. I had mets to the lung, and numerous nodes: in the centre of my chest, neck and a large mass in right breast. I started on Abraxane and Herceptin, and had a complete response, and was declared NED. Twelve months later, another lump in same breast, so had lumpectomy and started a clinical trial for TDM-1. More progression whilst on the trial, so left the trial and had a single mastectomy, which showed triple neg. My oncologist believes I had both triple neg and HER2+ at diagnosis. I then had rads on the large node in the centre of my sternum. so for over three years now, I have been NED. I am having scans on Friday (six monthly now!) hopefully NED will still be with me. Hopefully some others will chime in with their experiences also. xx
Posts.Title: Anyone else HER2+ with Lung mets adc21791 Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2014 08:10PM dawny wrote: Hi benjnate, if you are losing then, so am I! Lol.  I have never had any pain either, with mets to lung, nodes in chest wall and neck.  You are right the treatments are a whole different matter, mastectomy, rads and all the other s/e's.  I have never received a copy of my scans either, my onc just tells me what I need to know.  I am hormone neg, so even if you have been through all the hormonals, there are still a lot of combinations after that.  Are you worried that after reading you will feel pain, in places where you felt no pain before?  My brain would probably take me there too.  Hopefully there is nothing new to worry about Dawn xx

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2013 07:13PM dawny wrote: NickyJ, for me personally, I would stay on Herceptin. If it is not causing you any problems, too many side effects etc, I would stick with it. If It were to stop working then I would go to another Her2 targeted therapy such as Tykerb, but with Her2 and Stage IV, I wouldn't risk coming off it. My onc wouldn't even suggest it. Can you get another opinion? Fantastic news that you are NED! I had a period of NED also, I still had Herceptin through that time. Best wishes to you Dawn. Xx

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 01:26AM dawny wrote: When I had my PET, some of the injection fluid got on my skin and caused red, itchy swelling that lasted for months!! - I'm not sure if I am the only one this has happened to?  I hated the way it was injected also, I was in a small room. with a small round hole cut into the wall next to the bed, and the injection was given from the next room, that freaked me out, I thought Oh-Oh, they can't even be in the same room as me!  I also had to stay away from my childdren (and pregnant women) for a few hours after. In saying all that, I am glad I had a PET as it showed mets that would't have been picked up otherwise. Good luck Dawn
